texts.definition: The removal of players from active gameplay through active actions.
markups: <style="Definition">The removal of players from active gameplay through active actions.</style>

Many games let players or the system take aggressive actions or cause negative effects on other players, and this can result in the affected players not being able to play temporarily or permanently. This is called <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> because the actions leading to it is often diegetically represent as killing their avatars or characters.

Chess can be seen as an archetypical Player Killing game - the winning condition is to check mate the other player which in principle is the same as showing that one can kill the king. Although not necessary to win, players of Diplomacy and Risk greatly increase their chances of doing so by eliminating other players. In contrast, Monopoly does not have Player Killing even if player can be eliminated from the game. This since the elimination is caused indirectly by other players' actions and they have no way of distinguishing between which other players may be affected by their actions.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> as soon as it is possible for players to die in them since game masters can be seen as responsible for the deaths in nearly all cases. The exception is when players kill each other which of course is another instance of <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style>. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> all killings tend to be <style="CurrentLink">Player Killings</style> since all being that can be killed in these games are played by humans (the rare exception are mechatronic monsters such as the dragon in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragonbane">Dragonbane</link></style>).

Deathmatch games in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style>, found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20III">Quake III</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unreal%20Tournament%20series">Unreal Tournament series</link></style>, have <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> as the main goal. The more other players that a player manages to take out, the more points or "frags" he or she is rewarded. Players who are killed usually lose any special items and abilities gained and are transferred back to spawn points. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Frag">Frag</link></style> is an example of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style> built around the same core gameplay.  In the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style>, players can be killed online with negative consequences for their team but the deaths are temporary. Although not as common in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>, some early examples such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Genocide">Genocide</link></style> allow or even focus exclusively on <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style>.

That players can have their avatars or characters killed is always an explicit design choice, as is incorporating other design aspects that can effectively hinder them from participating in gameplay. This does however not always translate into <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> since those noticing players subject to these events must also perceive that somebody is actively trying to make this happen. This makes it central to the pattern that some form of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> can be linked to actions causing the events. This said, making <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> possible in games consist of deciding what actions and events can cause it, who can cause it, and what the effects of the killing is.

Combat is probably the most obvious action that can lead to Player Killing, but any way of directly causing Ability Losses or Damage can be used. If the use of Traps causes Player Killing is less clear - it depends on if those observing the trap being sprung perceive it as actively having placed there by Agents and that they can at least suspect who did this. Related to the question of what actions can kill is the question of what can be killed. Avatars and Characters are apparent choices here, used for example in the Unreal Tournament series and Dungeons & Dragons, but losing all Units in Risk shows that Player Killing does not need to be localized to specific Focus Loci. Diplomacy goes one step further - players are not eliminated due to lack of army Units but due to lack of supply centers.

Making it possible for other players to perform the actions that can lead to "player" deaths (i.e. having <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> in a <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style>) is a guaranteed way to ensure that players can identify the actions as ones coming from <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> controlled by <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> may or may not work depending on how much players perceive the individual <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> as being <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in their own right; for the same reason <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> can work but is less likely to do so than human players. <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> are more likely than other types of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> to support <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> since players can fall back on seeing the <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Master</link></style> as the source of the killing if the <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> are not seen as being <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. Games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> sometimes allow players to kill their own team members by <style="Link"><link="friendly-fire">Friendly Fire</link></style>. This pattern can support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and make for more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, it can also instantiate that create <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> between the killers and their victims regardless if the killing was on purpose or not. To regulate any type of <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style>, certain parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> can be made into <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> can lead directly to <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> if <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> is used in a game, and will do this eventually if <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> are used. An alternative perspective is that the use of <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> makes it possible to have <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> without <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> need to triggers <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> with some <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> or the pattern ceases to have negative consequences for those affected - if this is not done then the pattern may not even be noticed by those dying. Usually the <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="individual-penalties">Individual Penalties</link></style> even in games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, but they do affect the <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> anyway since these <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> can affect <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>. Independently of other <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> can indirectly give <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> to players by awarding <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> to those who kill them. Given that all these design choices in some way provide negative consequences to the targets of <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style>, the pattern basically always gives rise to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. This makes <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> easily cause disruptions in <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="tvt">TvT</link></style> gameplay and <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style> members consisting of players) and to avoid this, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Repeated%20Domination">Repeated Domination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Killings">Player Killings</link></style> are associated with <style="Link"><link="killcams">Killcams</link></style> more often than other types of killings are.

A rather paradoxical way of having Player Killing is to have unique Quick Time Events injected into some other type of gameplay. Although Quick Time Events do not easily give player impressions that anybody with agency is trying to kill them, the specificity with which the events themselves were designed can make player feel that the game designers are actively trying to kill them at that point in the games.
Quite obviously, <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> more difficult or impossible to do.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> removes players from gameplay it gives them <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> but can also lead to <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> if combine with <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> or the loss of one's last <style="Link"><link="lives">Life</link></style>. The possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> naturally gives rise to <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> to players, although how intensely this is experienced depends on the actual <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> of the <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> given for killing. The <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> is usually not as drastic if the <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> does not lead to <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>.

In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, the possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Player Killing</style> leads to reciprocal <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations for the players since they are potential or real threats to each other.
